number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I wanted to like this game. I really, really did. I played this for days, almost obsessively. It almost seemed like it was starting to get better, after many hours of having it constantly crash on me, I got into the habit of saving compulsively. After losing progress, hours upon hours of progress I'd start anew, stronger, faster, better prepared. But I don't think it was ever as fun as it seemed at the time. It was horribly tedious. I often had another game going on another system at the same time, as I waited for things to happen in the background. That's not a game. That's a simulation. And if I wanted to play a simulation, I'd run one with more polish and more things that were interesting to watch. This has neither. I'm certain there's something similar, better, out there. Find it. Play that instead. Don't waste your time like I did.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
FREEZE! Before you even think about buying this game, let me ask you a few questions. Do you like unfinished games that try to pass themselves off as "finished"? Hopefully not.Do you like extremely buggy and unplayable games that make vanilla Bethesda games pale in comparison? You really shouldn't!And finally, do you like wasting money on a game that promised continual updates? Of course not!"Towns" is the epitome of unrealized potential. Lazy developers took what would have been a decent time-wasting game and somehow managed to turn it into a mess. This pile of slop caused a backlash worthy of a Penny Arcade article.http://www.penny-arcade.com/report/article/the-perils-of-greenlight-how-towns-enraged-a-community-by-selling-a-game-th It was published in 2012 and still rings true over a year later.In short, please DO NOT buy this game ever. Ever. Under any circumstances. Thank you for your time.

												A Cautionary tale of how easy it is to get duped in todays global community. People want to believe in indy developers, because some incredibly unique and interesting experiences sometimes come from unexpected places. Unfortunately, right from the start of this games release, you could tell it was not where it should be, despite peoples support and the developers initial passion. All of that interest trailed off into nothingness very quickly, and now all of the initial supporters are left with a scar in their libraries.Dead project. Read other reviews for much better and complete alternatives.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Don't buy this.  Don't even consider it.I made the mistake of thinking this was a near-finished product that would be a bit easier to play than Gnome Fortress.  Not as complex but you know- a town simulator of SOME degree.  So I bought it more than a year ago.  The "tutorial" was garbage, as was the interface, the gameplay- basically everything was atrocious to one degree or another.  I promised to never touch it again until it was released in a finished state.News: IT WILL NEVER BE FINISHED.  Seriously.  Look at http://www.townsgame.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=11402.  They're done "updating it."Basically, this was a Greenlight product that was released before it should have been.  This is the one game that made me completely cautious of ever supporting any Early Access title whatsoever- AND THIS WASN'T EVEN EARLY ACCESS.  IT WAS RELEASED AS A FINISHED PRODUCT.  FOR 15 DOLLARS.This is a perfect example of what developers have the potential to do with your money.  Promise to make finished products and then back off and reap the rewards without any reprimand.  Sure, it sucks that the developer got burned out but he should have realized what he was doing before he was able to put this on Steam as a completed game.  And shame on Steam for allowing it.Don't buy it.  Don't touch it.  Just don't.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I hate to give bad reviews, but this game deserves it.  I was one of the many who jumped in early when this game was first released, mainly on the promise of what the devs said it would become.  I played the game a lot back in late 2012 and early 2013 and enjoyed it for the most part, but there were lots of things that still needed to be fixed, most notably the AI and the way it would handle performing tasks with your villagers.Reinstalled and played the game again a few months ago.....and found that nothing had changed in almost 2 years!  Reading about how the original dev abandoned the game and "sold" the rights to someone else is almost heartbreaking.  Indie games have a bad name with a lot of casual gamers because of behavior like this, and I'm ashamed that I contributed to this jerk walking away with more than $2 million in sales.

												I hate to give bad reviews, but this game deserves it.  I was one of the many who jumped in early when this game was first released, mainly on the promise of what the devs said it would become.  I played the game a lot back in late 2012 and early 2013 and enjoyed it for the most part, but there were lots of things that still needed to be fixed, most notably the AI and the way it would handle performing tasks with your villagers.Reinstalled and played the game again a few months ago.....and found that nothing had changed in almost 2 years! number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I played this game back when it was in alpha, back when there was still active development and a very active community. A friend of mine did a Let's Play of it and I enjoyed what I saw and played. Sadly, the last developer has finally called it quits, and I personally doubt this game will ever leave its alpha/beta state. It is fun micromanaging your town, trying to get immigrants to come to it and attract heroes to it as well, but the food system seriously needs to be reworked. My villagers can go all the way down to the bottom of my mine before needing to come back up again to eat, and since your town can experience hunger lock (Where you don't have any food at all and all villagers can't do anything due to starvation), expect a massive kill off if your food supply ever dwindles to an incredibly low number.There was a lot of potential behind this game, enough potential that I threw my money behind it back in 2011. Sadly, that potential will never be truly realized since its own developers and the last man working on this game gave up on it. If there ever is a Towns 2, I will not buy it due to the lack of interest the developers had in the first game.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												This is a game I would turly like to love. It's got a great concept, and really is quite fun. That said, the developers ruined the community. There are tons of "little things" that if fixed would make this an amazing game. However the devs have abandoned the game, and don't seem to have any intention on fixing it. It should be one of the best games of all time, but instead it's large number of tiny, small, problems renders the game tedious to play. If they would just fix that...  But they wont. Save your money. Don't buy the game. It's sad, I really want to like it, but your time and money is better spent in other games of this genere.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												The game used to be really good. But then the devs changed one little thing, that ruined it for me entirely.To get a higher population you used to need happiness. Happiness was achieved due to idleness (no work).This made somehow sense and was somewhat easy to achieve (the rest of the game is time consuming enough, so that was fine). But now they changed that. Being overworked and being idle is decreasing happiness now... To maintain a mix between idleness and workload you have to insanely manage and switch work groups of citizens in a tedious, time consuming, boring and annoying way.The game was fine, but now I can't recommend it anymore.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												By far the worst thing that could have happened to the opening days of Valve's (now beloved) Greenlight system. It was a game with so much promise--but which fizzled under poor care and lousy management from devs who (seemingly) simply had no interest in their community beyond the potential for money making. Despite valiant efforts by some few out there, this game is a dud, a broken piece of potential doomed to forever drift the landscape of Steam on the backs of the dollars many hopeful fans (myself included) spent toward its grand debut.This is no Terraria, no Gnomoria, no Dwarf Fortress or Minecraft. Any of those games would be a fine alternative, and I would recommend you turn their way instead.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Excitedly coaxed into buying Towns by a friend I was incredbily dissapointed. Towns is nothing but a reskin of Dwarf Fortress (A FREE game with graphics mod already available and better also for free) with no intresting mechanics, a poor tutorial that will frustrate those not familiar with Dwarf Fortress, among techinical issues I experienced (frame drops galore on Mac). Towns is also infamous for being one of the first projects taken off of Steam Early Access. That basically means the dev, knowing it was unfinished, decided to take his project off leaving the current version available with no future updates. An unfinished project that sets a terrible, unfortunate precident for furture projects in the Early Access program.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Unfinished game that somehow jumped from "alpha" to a finished game in the span of a week. At launch day, the game had such devastating bugs that made it mostly unplayable, and only some of those fatal bugs have been fixed in the year after the launch. There isn't really much actual gameplay involved, that portion of the game is out of balance and broken. Most of the things in-game don't actually do anything, they're just decoration and "make believe". Once you get food production running (and half of that is broken due to new patches implementing flawed animal feeding system etc), there's no longer anything interesting to see. Unless you like wasting your time building pointless things. I suppose some people do like that, but I don't. I would've actually liked to see some of that "city management" in the game instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												The game has an interesting concept and was the first Greenlight title.  Take a typical RPG setting and control the town instead of the heroes.  Your job is to build up sufficient infrastructure to attract and keep heroes happy for...some reason.  Who knows.Most of the 36 hours I spent playing were staring at the game in frustration trying to get it to work.  It has some similarities to Dwarf Fortress but it felt like I didn't have as much control.As others have said, get Gnomoria instead.  Cannot recommend this game to anyone.However I must give Towns at least a 1/10.  Due to its incredibly broken and frustrating nature, I had to look up help on YouTube and that led me to discovering Sips for the first time.  So thank you Towns for helping me find one of my favorite YouTubers.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2012
												In a word, Unfinished.In many -- Towns is a promising, but rough experience. Nothing seems to work quite as intended, the UI is a little finicky, mouse clicks don't always register in the right place (if at all), and digging is a nightmare. The further down you dig, the more erratic the mouse behavior becomes.At 15$, I'd say the price is steep -- comparing to Minecraft, which released at a similar price, the level of functionality is far less. Though then again, the requisite functionality is far greater in the case of Towns. However, this game is flawed for a far simpler reason, it was released onto steam with no notice that it was an unfinished, alpha game -- I'm an alpha-player, I love to play and watch as a game evolves, and I am _more likely_ to purchase an alpha game than many non-alpha games. I know many of my friends feel the same way, but  this game released to steam (via Greenlight) purporting to be a fully-ready 1.0 release, and that's just not what it is.I say wait. Maybe get it if the price drops to the 2-5$ range. It has potential to be quite good, if the development continues, but everything about the more general practice smells of a smash and grab on my wallet, and I don't much care for it.Weak accept on potential, Strong Reject on Honesty.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												I'll keep this short, This game has a learning curve thats quite steep, and it will be about 3 games before you figure out the basics. By the time you have a thriving town that can sustain itself you'll feel very acomplished. Soon though, things stop being so rewarding. Your townies are irritating at best, they can die from starvation because they straded themself 2 blocks high wile building, or drown because their path took them into water. Your buildings will very quickly trade estetics for fuctionality, possibaly a gribe for someone only as perfectionist as myself. There is nothing really to do after you figured everything out, because besides for a stray orge or something random like that the challenge is gone.I'm not saying not to buy this game, if its on sale by all means buy it, the learning curve wile give you enough entirtainment at least. But, this game is buggy and unpolished, and updates are nearly non existant, so it is a risk.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I bought Towns on sale just over a year ago...in that time it has received a few updates and undergone some changes.  However, this does not change the fact that this game left an utterly appalling impression upon me not only with the game but with the people working on it.  The tutorials were shamefully unhelpful, the gameplay was unintuitive, and the art style was unique but lead to an overall crude feel due to the games clunky play.As time has passed I'd expected this game to get refined some and updated to assauge some of the issues I had...but to this date the progress has been glacially slow and it remains the same lump of an overcomplicated mess that it always was.  Perhaps I'm being overly spiteful given my own impressions, but I can't for the life of me find any redeeming features about this game after it has remained the same awful product for so long.It's possible that you might enjoy this game, but I would heartily advise in-depth research about it, if not choosing a different product outright.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I originally bought this with the thought of "Woah cool, a town simulator!" in my mind.  After all, the screenshots showed some very epic looking towns, and the game wasn't in the Early Access category. (meaning it wasn't an alpha/beta, but rather a full release)Boy was I in for a surprise.. and not the good kind.I can sum up this game in one single word - Awful.  There was barely a tutorial involved, so I had no idea what I was doing.  I started up a game and within minutes my villagers with their fantastic AI decided to disregard all common sense and took it in turns to throw themselves at a monster, resulting in most of my population dying right away.  Those who survived died of starvation a few in-game days later because I had no idea how I was meant to feed them, despite throwing food down right infront of them.The game is filled with bugs, and there's been very little care and attention given to the game from the devs.  They've tried to pass off this game as being a full release, yet it's clearly still in alpha stage.  There's been many players complaining and demanding answers from the devs, but their cries seem to fall upon deaf ears.  Now that the devs have made a cool $2mil from this game, they couldn't care less, and it clearly shows.Don't buy this game, not even for a laugh/joke.  These developers don't deserve any of your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												As a patron of Minecraft, I very much enjoyed musing the idea of having multiple people placing the blocks, especially in the form of a functioning town rather than a purely aesthetic one. Towns has the potential to be that awesome crossover, but it is not. Although listed as a finished game it feels very much as an Alpha. The control over the "Townies" is extremely limtied, and each map begins the same way : a horrible struggle.The question is why is it a horrible struggle? Right off the bat there are a number of monsters covering the surface of the map, many are able to kill a townie 1 versus 1. The townies will engage anything they encoutner and unlike the "Heroes" do not ever disengage until one of them is dead. So very early on your main task is gathering resources but in very controlled ways to avoid your townies by chance encounter a monster.So you lost some townies, how does one get them back? Well you will need to have rooms built individually for each town plus any extras you want, they must be well furnished and food must flow in abundance, this together allows them to maintain their happiness which will entice others to join. Here is the kicker: work quickly saps happiness, so when you lose a townie or two the others must work twice as hard to provide happiness. I am sure you can see the paradox happenning.Ofcourse many other small time problems persist throughout the game which make building anything close to the promos provided to be a long, long way away. Sure this sounds like the right approach, you cannot build a city over night, but the truth is you will spend many weeks before seeing anything resembling a couple huts.In conclusion this game was greenlit with the hopes of it being grown, expanded and ultiamtely polished. Here is how it looks. Greenlit - September 11th, 2012Last Monthly Update - September 21th, 2013Date of Review - June 24th, 2014It has been nearly a year to the date of this review since anything signficant was changed and it will be a surprise to see another.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												By general standard this is not a "complete game"Graphic of this game is....let's say retro.AI in this game is poor.Last update v14 was released in September, 2013. V13 was released in May, 2013. The changes that was implemeneted in these patches contains very few contents and minimun bug fixes. It seems like the developers just don't care or hoping that modders can fix everything for them.LIke every other games in the same genre that's on greenlight, AI in this game is poor.and there's a breakdown of their "about the game" info page on steam"The game brings a fresh new take on the city building/management genre by introducing many RPG features. "Nope, there are many others just like it, the game is heavily inspired by many other game and it offers nothing "fresh" and "new"."n Towns you manage a settlement on top of an active dungeon. Instead of playing the hero who delves deep into the dungeon, how about playing the town that houses and caters to the hero's needs?"Heroes don't need jack. All it takes to attract heroes is to boost your population and have an area set up as "tavern". The "tavern" area doesn't have to be enclosed. Meaning that heores will be perfectly fine sleeping on the ground looking at stars just because you painted a 3x3 block purple and called it "inn".There is no intereaction between your townsfolk and heroes at all. They have very poor AI and die very easily if you are new to the game. Gearing up these heroes is not an easy process and sometimes random. You need to put the items on their path or "hangout" area and hope that they pick up the gear you want them to wear. "Both the RPG and strategic aspects will be fleshed out over a series of sprawling dungeons."The only RPG elements involved in the dungeons is "there are mobs, they drop loot". The only strategic aspect of the game is "pray to the gods that when you dig down, you don't dig directly into a group of mobs because your townsfolk are dumb and they will not flee" and "dig open dungeon walls bit by bit and hope your townsfolk don't try to engage the mobs"There is minimun strategy and minimun RPG elements in this game. Townsfolk has a hunger bar, a sleep bar and a happiness bar and that's it. There is no "leveling" for your townsfolk and leveling for heores is meaningless."Attract travelling heroes that will independently explore the dungeons below, fight off monsters, gain levels, special skills and collect the best loot they can find in order to clear the land of all evil!"Like stated above, there is no interactions between you and the heroes. About the loots, here's the funny part. Once you clear a dungeon, it's best not to collect loot from the dungeon because there's a billion of trash loot lying on the ground. Heroes will pick up gears when they feel like it. It's best to leave those in the dungeon.The best loot is often not dropped in the dungeon. Once you have a market set up, travelling merchants will come and they will randomly sell you the best gear in the game. So in order to get the best loot in game, you priorites a market over anything else. Regardless your progression in the game, you will be able to buy best gears purely based on luck."Craft unique weapons, trade with exotic items, obtain randomized loot, set up devious death traps and build a settlement capable of holding back the forces that come up from the depths!"Mobs in the dungeon will come to your town only when a hero engages them with low health and decides to run away. Those mobs will not stop chasing the fleeing hero until one of them is dead. This normally leads to a few townies dying because of the poorly designed AI. There is nothing unique about the weapon and item designs. They are very generic items. I wouldn't describe loots to be "randomized". 90% of them are trash loots and 99% of them are just junk on the ground waiting to be sold when a merchant arrives (if that merchant has enough money and willing to buy these crap. normally they just don't want them at all).In summary, this game is not worth its asking price. Yes, it's about the price of a very fancy subway sandwitch in Canada but I assure you that you will get more satisfaction out of that sandwitch than this game. If you are desprately looking for a game like this, wait for it to go on sale and do not expect any updates because it's not very likely. There is a modding scene for this game. It's small and I suggest you to go to their forum and check out more information there. Simply google "towns" and you'll be able to access their website and forum. Thank you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												The game is broken.  Bottem line.Its hard to describe because the game WAS (the devs gave up once they got the $) getting patched so broken things were removed... and then new broken things were added in but here is a list of what I found the most broken.1. Building is not fun.  There is no easy copy and paste for buildings.  And if there is, then it is hidden under the games terrible interface.  It can take a lot of effort of placing certain building blocks in certain orders to build a house with the clunky building controls.  But then if you have to do it at least 20 more times if you want to get townies.  It can take a while.2.  The interface is horrible.  The labels are off.  It just felt clunky.  First you have to click one menu button, then you have to click a sub menu button and find what you want.  Then if its something like wheat and you want it to be bread you have to go into more menus and submenus to find what you want.  The bread making tools and blocks should all be on the same page not scattered around.3.  Your villagers are idiots.  They have no clue how to do anything without dieing.  Horrible monsters attacking?  Don't worry, your villagers will just stand there and die instead of running.  Sometimes they run indoors but most of the time go around doing what they normally do.  Their are even some maps with randomly wandering enemys, I dont have a problem with that but they do it so poorly in Towns.  In the snow maps one stray yeti can just wander on over and kill EVERYONE.  Also they will run though hell and back...to get stone.  I have seen them go on some brave runs just to get a basic resource.  You got to give them credit.  They will stop are nothing to drag that junk back to the stockpile... even if they all die in the process.4.  The monsters that attack your village come out of THIN AIR.  You would think they would come from any dungeon entrances you have but they seem to pop out of midair at times.  5.  Monsters are either really OP or really easy.  I watched a guard kill five slimes once.  Then I watched three guards with iron gear just get massacred by ONE wearpig. (Which is actually a common enemy.  Any normal pig could be a wearpig.)  6.  Hero's are broken.  I must have done EVERYTHING I could think of to attract a hero.  They never come.  They are broken.  That or the system is terrible.  Either way the game dosen't explain things and after browsering the web for a while I still can't get damn Heros.  Worst part is.  You need heros to clear dungeons, but you can never get them it seems.7  The way you make your townies happy is stupid.  They mainly get happy from eating.  Problem is, if you have food that fills them up a lot and dosen't make them eat as often.  YOU GET PUNISHED.  I actally tested this at one point by making bread fill 1500%.  Sure enouth happyness dropped to zero because they were not eating.   You can do a few other things like have badger fights (which seem broken) and put decorations but it seems food is what they want the most.  So remember, just spam cakes.  Anything that actually fills their stomachs is bad.  They don't want to be full.  THey want to be hungry.  Makes zero sense.    8.  Last thing I am going to mention is the dungeons...THEY ARE EVERYWHERE.  It seems I can't dig down at all without hititng a dungeon on most map.s  I just wan't some stone but the game shoves the dungeons everywhere.  They cover the whole map when they should be deep underground and have SMALL entrances.    Now things may have changed since I wrote this but this is what I encountered when I played the game.  And maybe some of the issues I mentioned have easy fixes but there is a problem...THE GAME SHOULD EXPLAIN IT THEN.  There is no tutorial.  Well there claims to be one but it just starts you off on fixed map without telling you much.  You have to find the message log and it tells you to do basic stuff.  Nice they have one at all but it never explains the fine details of the game.  Just the basic crude that I could probably figure out just by expermenting.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												As a patron of Minecraft, I very much enjoyed musing the idea of having multiple people placing the blocks, especially in the form of a functioning town rather than a purely aesthetic one. Towns has the potential to be that awesome crossover, but it is not. Although listed as a finished game it feels very much as an Alpha. The control over the "Townies" is extremely limtied, and each map begins the same way : a horrible struggle.The question is why is it a horrible struggle? Right off the bat there are a number of monsters covering the surface of the map, many are able to kill a townie 1 versus 1. The townies will engage anything they encoutner and unlike the "Heroes" do not ever disengage until one of them is dead. So very early on your main task is gathering resources but in very controlled ways to avoid your townies by chance encounter a monster.So you lost some townies, how does one get them back? Well you will need to have rooms built individually for each town plus any extras you want, they must be well furnished and food must flow in abundance, this together allows them to maintain their happiness which will entice others to join. Here is the kicker: work quickly saps happiness, so when you lose a townie or two the others must work twice as hard to provide happiness. I am sure you can see the paradox happenning.Ofcourse many other small time problems persist throughout the game which make building anything close to the promos provided to be a long, long way away. Sure this sounds like the right approach, you cannot build a city over night, but the truth is you will spend many weeks before seeing anything resembling a couple huts.In conclusion this game was greenlit with the hopes of it being grown, expanded and ultiamtely polished. Here is how it looks. Greenlit - September 11th, 2012Last Monthly Update - September 21th, 2013Date of Review - June 24th, 2014It has been nearly a year to the date of this review since anything signficant was changed and it will be a surprise to see another.

												I don't have much to say about the gameplay of this game since I gave up on it a couple of months earlier, for it's buggy, controls are tedious, often gives you literally instant death starts, and the graphics are just outright horrendous, reminiscent of cheap point-and-click adventure games. And most importantly - the developers gave up too. It has been at least five full months since the latest update. When you flood the market with thousands of greenlit indie, early access games, there're bound to be duds. I understand that this game was still early in development when I got it and things indeed might turn sour since life is so unpredictable, but it's still so frustrating that what you bought at a real game's price suddenly went silent with updates without giving any real explanation beforehand.For all intents and purposes we could say that this game is effectively dead now. Consider getting Gnomoria if you liked this game's concept, it's currently in active development and even though the dev "team" seems to be just one man, he (or she?) at least gives consistent weekly updates with real content and interacts with players regularly.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												The bottom line:  This game has an interesting premise.  Rather than casting you as the hero who goes into the dungeons in search of fame and glory, you are in charge of building and organizing the town above the dungeon where the hero rents his hotel room and buys his weapons.  That said, this game really isn't as much fun as it sounds.  It is an extensive exercise in MICRO-MANAGEMENT.  If you can get it for REALLY REALLY CHEAP, then it's worth playing if you enjoy games like the original Warcraft (the original, not WoW!!) or Sim City.  I have to say though, I am not a fan of any game where the townsfolk will starve to death if you just leave them alone for a while.You start out with a handful of citizens and absolutely no town.  Your first 4 hours of play will be dedicated to gathering food and setting up a farm so your citizens don't starve to death (which they will do QUITE OFTEN if you are not paying attention!!).  Your next 6 hours of play will be dedicated to mining a few piles of rock and mud, chopping down a few trees, and building some basic workshops for your citizens to work in.  Then you'll spend another 3 hours setting up a kitchen and a bakery, as well as some animal farms so your people can eat something besides apples.  Only after that will you worry about building a tavern for traveling heroes to stay and eat at.  And only after THAT will you start digging down into the dungeon.  Digging into the dungeon and having a tavern with at least one open tavern bedroom are the requirements for heroes to start coming to your town.  Different types of heroes will come based on how deep into the dungeon you are, how many people live in your town, and what type of furniture you have in the tavern bedroom.  Once you do get into the dungeons, there are a ton of monsters which will probably kill everyone who finds their way down the  tunnel.  But there are more resources in the dungeon that you can't find on the surface, like iron, copper, silver, and gold... and you need a ton of those to build better weapons and armor for your city guards.  Meanwhile, you might randomly have a Werepig go berserk on your town and KILL EVERYONE, or you might have a sudden invasion by monsters from the forest and THEY ALL DIE.  But NEVER FORGET... the number one priority AT ALL TIMES has to be food production or else your entire city will starve because the citizens are as stupid as rocks.One good thing about this game is that it is VERY EASY to create mods for it.  You can mess with the amount and placement of various resources, enemies, even mountains and plants.  If you want to get deeper into the config files, you can even change the number of citizens you start with, alter citizen and hero attributes, and even alter enemies to make them easier or harder.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												I don't have much to say about the gameplay of this game since I gave up on it a couple of months earlier, for it's buggy, controls are tedious, often gives you literally instant death starts, and the graphics are just outright horrendous, reminiscent of cheap point-and-click adventure games. And most importantly - the developers gave up too. It has been at least five full months since the latest update. When you flood the market with thousands of greenlit indie, early access games, there're bound to be duds. I understand that this game was still early in development when I got it and things indeed might turn sour since life is so unpredictable, but it's still so frustrating that what you bought at a real game's price suddenly went silent with updates without giving any real explanation beforehand.For all intents and purposes we could say that this game is effectively dead now. Consider getting Gnomoria if you liked this game's concept, it's currently in active development and even though the dev "team" seems to be just one man, he (or she?) at least gives consistent weekly updates with real content and interacts with players regularly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game had so much potential. I put a lot of hours into building several towns. While I would not necessarily call this 'abandonware' just yet as there have been updates, the feeling is that it's been put so far on the backburner that we will never see a completed product or, by the time we do, what will be the point? Something better or newer will come out to take it's place.The developer insisted that the product is playable upon time of release, after Early Access was terminated. While the game was playable, the words were decieiving. A playable game should not be released if there are still countless bugs to be fixed and several key features that have not been added to the game.It's such a shame, because the game had great potential and an idea for a somewhat unique mechanic. But I can't recommend this game to anyone, unless you are looking for examples of how a good concept can go bad, learn the idea, and take time to figure out how to improve upon it with your own game. Even if the developer would fix the bugs and implement all originally discussed and intended features as described, I just have no faith in the developer and this game anymore.R.I.P. Towns.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2013
												The idea of this game is kind of cool.  Unfortunatly that is all this game really is, an idea.  There are a lot of unfinished game-play mechancis. you know, interesting ideas, that just do not go anywhere.For the most part, you start a town, get your food production going and then you need to attract heros to clear out the gaint dungeon undernearth your town.  So what do you end up doing with most of your time once you get past the startup phase?You just watch the heroes bumble around and try and clear out one level of the dungeon.  And when they are done with that?  You just get to watch them do the same thing on the next level.  Thats all you do. Oh sure, you can build stuff for the sake of building stuff, like a garden or place decortave statues, but something really useful?  No.My reccomendation is to NOT buy this game.  Maybe in a few years the game-play will be fleshed out more, but right now, there isn't much, if any, of a game here.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I so wanted to see this game finished. As it stands, there are far too many bugs in it and the AI periodically commits suicide doing dumb stuff forcing you to repetitively micro manage everything. Imagine the old sims games where you had to tell your sims to go to the bathroom or they♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants, now imagine the old sims games where you had to micro manage 50 sims spreadout in a ridiculously huge area trying to click on them to each tell them to go take a♥♥♥♥♥♥before they♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants.I dunno where I am going with this, all I know is that the devs have abandoned the game and are treating all the paying customers like absolutely garbage. The game's AI is god awful and lots of seemingly simple things have repetitive and/or unnecessarily time-consuming or drawn-out ways of doing things and you will spend majority of your time making sure your AI don't kill themselves by being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.The micro management doesn't only involve the AI, just controlling your resources is a massive headache. As a person who has programmed several Unity games, one of them ended up with 2 million plays, I have absolutely no idea what possessed the developer to take this game in such a sensely complex direction. I can understand that not all game programmers are 'game designers' and are incapable of seeing the flaws in their design, but♥♥♥♥♥♥at least run it by a friend who can give you honest feedback. This game went horribly wrong at the beginning and the dev likely abandoned it due to needing to spend too much work redoing 90% of the game to make it actually make sense.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												If Gabe were as awesome as we'd like to believe, he'd give us a $15 voucher for another game. The best analogy I can come up with:Gaben is a wealthy pharmacist. He knows his job is to acquire new prescriptions for his large community. Now, there are so many new drugs coming out every day, that Gaben has to ask his community, "What new drugs should we offer at the pharmacy?"The community heard some neat things about this Townsicol, a do-everything drug. Gaben can only assume that his community knows what they want, even though they don't often know how to get the information about the pharmaceutical companies that made the drug, at least not as profieciently as Gaben. The people assure Gaben that yes, we want Townsicol in the pharmacy!So Gaben orders Townsicol, even though it hasn't gone through proper FDA qualifications.The people buy up their prescriptions of their new drug and GOSH! IT TASTES AWFUL! OH GOD! IT'S GIVEN ME DYSENTERY! WHY GA-BGLALARBGB-BEN WHY-ARHGBLARBL?!But Gaben, watching his customers launch projectile vomit at one another, is distressed. He feels bad for his customers, but THEY ASKED FOR THIS. He brought it in as a special order and the man that sold it to him has completely disappeared like some peddler pushing snake oil! Worse, there are those, like yours truly, that watched everyone throw up, walked through that lake of vomit, waded to the counter in all the puke they had expelled, and bought a bottle of Townsicol for themselves.TL;DR game's bad; developers ran with the money; don't buy it, ♥♥♥♥♥.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												If Gabe were as awesome as we'd like to believe, he'd give us a $15 voucher for another game. The best analogy I can come up with:Gaben is a wealthy pharmacist. He knows his job is to acquire new prescriptions for his large community. Now, there are so many new drugs coming out every day, that Gaben has to ask his community, "What new drugs should we offer at the pharmacy?"The community heard some neat things about this Townsicol, a do-everything drug. Gaben can only assume that his community knows what they want, even though they don't often know how to get the information about the pharmaceutical companies that made the drug, at least not as profieciently as Gaben. The people assure Gaben that yes, we want Townsicol in the pharmacy!So Gaben orders Townsicol, even though it hasn't gone through proper FDA qualifications.The people buy up their prescriptions of their new drug and GOSH! IT TASTES AWFUL! OH GOD! IT'S GIVEN ME DYSENTERY! WHY GA-BGLALARBGB-BEN WHY-ARHGBLARBL?!But Gaben, watching his customers launch projectile vomit at one another, is distressed. He feels bad for his customers, but THEY ASKED FOR THIS. He brought it in as a special order and the man that sold it to him has completely disappeared like some peddler pushing snake oil! Worse, there are those, like yours truly, that watched everyone throw up, walked through that lake of vomit, waded to the counter in all the puke they had expelled, and bought a bottle of Townsicol for themselves.TL;DR game's bad; developers ran with the money; don't buy it, ♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												... Ok, let's be clear here, I did love this game... only because it had this mechanic you can abuse to get more villagers in towns in the before time, I think this game could be better if it WASN'T SO ♥♥♥♥ING HARD AND REPETITIVE I mean, seriously, all you ♥♥♥♥ing doing is watching you people gather♥♥♥♥♥♥ and watching them die, I did love this game... and some, SOME enjoyment is credible... but is highly unlikely, being no objective, which... is most indie games... I can't really hate on that point... but I CAN HATE EVERYTHING ELSE ABOUT THE GAME. Ok... lemme... press enter and see what I should hate about first... hmm...Ok, if you ever played, watched gameplay, or... idk, ♥♥♥♥ing heard the sound track you've noticed that it ♥♥♥♥ing loops, and it's soooooo uninteresting, I mean, seriously, you have a annoying and ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ track that ♥♥♥♥ING LOOPS, and no, that's not the worst part.The worst part is the A.I, it's like "Oh, I'm low on health, I should just keep fighting the monster" instead of just running away, Oh, and you wanna know the funny thing? THE HEROS FLEE, NOT THE CIVILIANS! the heros have apprently honored in Flight or fight class... The one thing that is super dumb that I find is... why did the remove that mechanic? I mean... ugh... I wish I can get a refund... but... ugh, just ♥♥♥♥ this game... don't even bother looking at it...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game is addictive and has so much potential to be great, but right when you start asking yourself where this game has been all your life, something bugs, or glitches, or you can't do something in the game that seems obvious.  I bought this game in beta and was excited to see how it would come out.  I guess I bought it on the last update, because there have been no more and now I hear that this game has been dropped from production.  I am dissapointed in the devs for throwing out what could be a potential classic, and I'm mad at steam for selling me a game that is still being made, then allowing the game to stop.  I had fun with it and if anything I think the modding community will pick up where the devs left off and give this game the polish it deserves.  I had fun with it and I tend to play it for days straight then don't play it for months then give it a few days again.  I would only reccomend this game if you are into modding, otherwise save your money because it is far from perfect, yet close, but at some times it's not even good, if that makes any sense.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Pending an Edit, I might change this in the future.This game has great potential, but it all fades after about 20hrs of gameplay.The early learning curve of the game is very steep. Infact, since there is no ingame help of any kind, you will be going to the internet to figure out some mechanics of this game.Villager path finding is always shortest route, regardless of danger. Hostile NPC's do have random and specific spawns, but more often then not I feel they are hunting me down.Building is somewhat confusing till you get the hang of it. The only drawback is, if you don't build in small sections the game seems to hang on larger designs. The same goes for most the resource managment. Even after giving out specific jobs, and setting priority's all my villagers do is eat and sleep.Fact is, this game has loads of pontential. But fails to deliver. At best this feels like an Alpha Version of a game.I do not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Interesting. Where did all the reviews go? Wow. Starting on a blank slate here, maybe?Let's be honest: The premise of Towns is as quirky as it is unique: You build a fantasy town OVER a monster-filled dungeon, so that heroes will come and explore said dungeon- and with your town being endared by the monsters but at the same time able to provide important services to the heroes the game clearly has a tongue-in-cheek approach to both town-building and fantasy tropes in general.Let's be honest: This is an early access game. So you can expect it isn't done yet. It allows you to build a diverse range of buildings and services, and heroes do occasionally pop up and do their thing, and yes, there are monsters.And that is the catch, the premise is really interesting but at this stage, the features that are in don't make for a very interesting game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This is a game that, as of yet, still has great potential. I worry, however, about the direction things are heading, based on the previous few updates adding some fluff (buried towns?) rather than refining core gameplay. I definitely enjoyed Towns at first. However, there are still other games doing the things that Towns tries to do, and doing them better. At the end of the day I think that I got my money's worth. It doesn't have any huge complications in further development from what I know (Unlike Godus's need to scrap in-game purchases) and I think that this game can still improve.-=-=-=-=-REVIEW EDIT: Not too long after I wrote this the game imploded. Don't buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This game was one of the first games picked by the Greelight community, and it seemed to have a lot of potential. But 2 years later, every hope i had for this game is now dead and buried, since the developer first abandoned it, then sold it to a third-party-dev, who abandoned it again. Playing it feels like playing an Early-Access game, and a lot of important fetures are either incomplete or missing. If you really have 12€ to spare and want to weep over the games former bright future, don't buy it. Support some other developer who will use the money to finish their game, instead of trying to sell the unfinished first part to develop a second part (which you will be charged for a second time).

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Oh how I wish I didn't have to give this game a negative review. I can tell, that this game, if it were to be finished, would be a game I'd cherish. The aspect of this game, the functionality, the rpg/sandbox/strategy elements of this game are all my cup of tea when it comes to PC games. Unfortunately, I cannot give this "would be" game the approval for others to invest their time and money into. Every feature this game has to offer is unfinished and unpolished. Perhaps because there was a lot of tweaking and additional content planned for this game that have yet to be implemented. I really hope this game isn't dead for good, but it has dug itself into a rut with its massive amounts of negative reviews. I cannot disagree with them. It is wrong for the current developer to sell it as a complete game. Unless this game gets any further development, my negative review shall remain.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												As it is this is not a game you want to spend more than $5 or less on. If you are looking to spend a long time building and making slow or no progress this is it. There are a few tricks to pick up that allows you to actually achieve some progress but due to the programming allowing your townies to starve because they have traveled to far, or gotten themselves stuck its still a slow and frustrating game. I keep hoping that the developers will adress some of these issues and still nothing. The food issue is the worst as you can do nothing to adjust for it, once you go into the ground mining and exploring your townies will die and fast. The values for food and sleep run down to swiftly, and outside of stopping your townies from digging completely you can not keep them from entering the depths where once you go ten levels down they die from starvation. Some of the tools are intriguing, and fun to play with as long as you refrain from going past -10 in digging. Once you come to terms with these drawbacks its a fun little game. Oh yea to clear out the monsters in the dungeons you do get heros yet they are completely random and you must account for them as being three population wise thats how hard they hit your food supply. There is so much potential in this game and it is sad to see it left so broken. If given an overall score for entertainment, novelty, and playability at best its a 3 out of 10.

												Pros: Building your town one block at a time is good fun, and exploring the random environments is enjoyable,Cons: It contains a "happiness" mechanic that rewards you for not playing and -- annoyingly -- forces you to leave the game running on its own for long periods in order to advance well.Certainly worth a look, but lacks the long-term appeal of Terraria.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I´ve voted "No, i do not recommend this game" but i really would like to say: "Yes!"Why? This game really gave me some good time, cause i like the freedom in which you're able to build up a town, the retroish graphics and the possibility to alter the game due editing some xml files. Unfortunately the problems start right there: Since the engine limits the world to a 64*64 cube, you have to choose between dungeon roaming and building high up in the air, when altering the world generation (only a change in values). Last one is my favorite playstyle... or: would be, if the engine would not getting annoyingly laggy with more than 12 surface leves. There seem to be too many transparent blocks which affects the game as soon as you are giving more than two orders to your Townies. So, i am just not able to build high buildings without having a second lag, a second none, a second lag, a sec.. you get it. And that "really grinds my gears".Also, the menu is crap and the tutorial basically only explains how to move your mouse from left to right and bottom to top. Furthermore, there are some serious bugs, which are a total pain in the a**. Check out the Community Hub's discussion to get an idea of them, it is a long list.And yes, the devs spoofed those who bought this game, cause updates came in irregularily, were minor and the communication to us customers is worth mentioning.At the moment rumors say the devs are looking for someone new to heritage this project. We´ll see.After all Towns is a perfect example for everything which could go wrong with Steam's Greenlight/Early Access policy (or which mechanism else failed).I recommend to keep this game in mind, check for updates and buy it when the ♥♥♥♥♥torm moves on.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												(Game has been abandoned by the developers at what feels like late alpha / early beta)I haven't really read any of the other reviews, except a quick glance at some of the positives, as I don't want mine to be influenced by them in any way. I will note that many of the positive reviews seem to be accidental recommendations, and Steam needs to remove that as the default option :PSo.. Towns. Well it's a decent base for a game, and I generally enjoyed the parts of it which worked properly, but that's really where it ends. If you try, you can perhaps push 20 hours or so out of the game, but ultimately the bugs and complete lack of content and polish will leave you despairing at the developers, who have abandoned this game.The screenshots paint a pretty picture of flourishing towns and wonderful defenses, but it doesn't really apply to a real game, and you'll find yourself becoming frustrated at how fiddly everything is and how face-palmingly unintelligent the AI is, being almost unable to self regulate their most basic requirements. They almost seem suicidal.. but given the state of the game, I won't hold it against them.Ultimately what you see in the screenshots is pretty much everything, and at it's unlikely best (visually). I strongly resent paying full price for games being brought to market which are late alpha/early beta, especially when the developers dump them and run off with the money because they don't really feel like doing it anymore. That's theft where I come from. I don't think the game was officially an 'Early Access' game? Just Greenlight perhaps, but either way I won't be buying a game until it's fully released from now on, and I wish Steam would pull this game off the store and stop putting it on sale. It's a skeleton of a game and will never be more than that.

Posted: December 8, 2012
												"Tell them why they shouldnt" I have played this game. I liked it a lot. However, the fact that the developers used this as a quick money grab disgusts me a lot.This game literally went from ALPHA to FULL RELEASE the moment they got greenlighted! Most of the features that are on the list arent even IN THE GAME YET. The community manager said it could take YEARS for the developers to get the game there. The store page sais "Towns is continually being developed and updated to bring you the best experience possible." Its deceiving as hell. It claims the game is finished and they are adding things to it now.But thats not the case, the AI is dumb as♥♥♥♥♥♥ you cant manage them at all, which is what this game is all about right? I wont bore you with examples. This game has a lot of potential, but right now its just a fast cash grab. I really recommend you try the demo first before buying it and if you buy it. KNOW YOUR BUYING AN UNFINISHED GAME.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												tl;dr - Game is abandoned and overpriced, but if you pick it up for $5 you get your money's worth and have a new game to spend some weekend afternoons playing.Years ago, this game was fun. Nothing in this game hadn't been done before, but it brought a lot of things together in an enjoyable package, and new content was being brought out that added facets to the idea of managing a town catering to adventurers and trying to survive the dangers of a D&D world. Now, the game is exactly the same. That's the problem; the end of Towns' beta came purely because the dev wanted more sales for less work.It's really too bad that the development of this game became something of a hot potato due to fewer sales than the original developer wanted. Towns was developing in an interesting direction, and at the end of the updates had started introducing some enjoyably complicated ways to use basic water channels to make tasks easier. However, it never got to a fully mature stage, instead slowly petering out with updates being smaller and much less often. Eventually, after everyone assumed the dev had already walked away, it was pawned off to make a little more money, to someone who promised new updates but never delivered.A lot of people are saying not to buy this game because it has been abandoned, and at full price I back that up. But I enjoy it still from time to time, knowing full well what kind of game it is. Maybe you will too?My recommendation to buy this game comes with the caveat that you should look more closely at what it is, maybe scan through the wiki, and see if you might enjoy it. You can always try it out for an hour, then refund it, you know? But for god's sake don't pay $15 dollars for this, $5 at most. Something to stick on the wishlist and pick up during a steam sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												From initial release the dev team of this game has mislead customers on Steam.  Initally it was released as a complete and playable version.  However, it hadn't hit it's full version number in beta yet.  The UI was terribly implemented, the pathing, AI, inclusion of god hand mechanics to work around lazy coding problems, and a plethora of truly unproffessional issues plagued the game.  To top it all off, there wasn't a patch for almost 4 months after release.  Last December the Dev threatened to quit the game and then quickly changed his mind during the holiday sale.  Since that initial release there has only been 5 patches of minimal consequence to ongoing issues of the game - in fact trying to add features to an already broken game has caused even more problems than before.Even though now that the Store Page has been updated to read, "Towns is continually being developed and updated to bring you the best experience possible," it simply isn't.  You can go months with zero dev updates on their work.  Patches are released up to 5 months period in between patches.  None of the prior mechanics implementations have been fixed.  And now the dev is saying he is trying to hire another coder.....The owner of this game is a self admitted full time employee of another company.  He has said on more than one occasion that they can't keep up with updates cause they have to work their jobs.  Don't support a game where the devs are not committed to it.  Let it die, and perhaps some of the more fanatic fans can take the code and do something legitimate with it.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												From initial release the dev team of this game has mislead customers on Steam.  Initally it was released as a complete and playable version.  However, it hadn't hit it's full version number in beta yet.  The UI was terribly implemented, the pathing, AI, inclusion of god hand mechanics to work around lazy coding problems, and a plethora of truly unproffessional issues plagued the game.  To top it all off, there wasn't a patch for almost 4 months after release.  Last December the Dev threatened to quit the game and then quickly changed his mind during the holiday sale.  Since that initial release there has only been 5 patches of minimal consequence to ongoing issues of the game - in fact trying to add features to an already broken game has caused even more problems than before.Even though now that the Store Page has been updated to read, "Towns is continually being developed and updated to bring you the best experience possible," it simply isn't.  You can go months with zero dev updates on their work.  Patches are released up to 5 months period in between patches.  None of the prior mechanics implementations have been fixed.  And now the dev is saying he is trying to hire another coder.....The owner of this game is a self admitted full time employee of another company.  He has said on more than one occasion that they can't keep up with updates cause they have to work their jobs.  Don't support a game where the devs are not committed to it.  Let it die, and perhaps some of the more fanatic fans can take the code and do something legitimate with it.

Said all this, I recommend to try it if you see a nice discount, as it's only a game in development.

												This game was Super fun, Addicting, and Great for a graphical version of Dwarven Fortress Lite. However I can NOT reccomend this game no matter how many hours I've put into it. In fact I will be requesting a refund from steam after this review. This is a green lit alpha game. Most of us bought it before even then. It had LOADS of potential. Sadly here is why I say don't buy it. THE DEV'S HAVE ABANDONED THIS GAME! After making loads of money off the prospect of a finished title. The programer has gone off to "Work on another title they are making." Well thanks for telling me not to buy that one either. Finish what you start. That is the mantra that should be followed. There are Many other games that are better. However this game had soul... until it was abandoned. They aren't going to release it a freeware either. "Because he may come back to it." Sorry I don't think people would have supported NOTCH if he stopped in the  middle of minecraft.  Currently they are looking for another "Java Programmer" but they've been looking for 3 months now. No telling how long before they told us. No I WILL NOT support a game that is abandoned half way through production.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21
												Got this game back when it was still alpha, for very cheap. Knowing it was alpha, and browsing the forums, the game was a very fun experience. There were contests, and a bunch of good spirited discussion, etc. I definitely had my moneys worth of enjoyment from this game. Sadly, devs started delaying new updates, kept cutting out parts of the game that were promised, and eventually "settled" that the game was finished in the current state, which let me tell you, is not even close to what it should be. From that point the game left its "alpha status", apparently went through a very short beta period, and it released here on Steam (I only have little time with the game here on steam, because I played a lot of the standalone version). Like it was a full game or something...The rest is history now, but in case you don't know, it goes something like this: The general public in steam find that the game is really lackluster for a full game, and complain. Devs promise to improve, despite insisting that the game is complete. At some point one of the devs simply disappears without warning. After some time, the guy reappears, saying that he had problems and he couldn't deal with the pressure the players put on him, or something of the sort... and promises to try and get back on the game again. Never heard of him since then...The game as it stands still has a ton of balance issues, incomplete features, and despite that I really enjoyed my time with the game, I doubt anyone can really enjoy it as it is today. The promise of future improvements and the community is what made the game fun, other than that I admit that it was pretty mediocre. I advise that noone buys this game, if anything to keep their moral integrity and not fund half-baked abandoned projects. If you still wanna buy it, at least be aware of what it is.Thanks for reading,Jon_jon13, self proclaimed "watergineer".

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Note: I posted a previous review but I want to elaborate on it now.Overall SummaryThis game is having tough times. Sure the devs have took the money and, almost entirly stopped development (They release fixes, and such). But this is because at this point I can say this game is done! It has many features to explore with alot of replayability in it, the Alpha may aswell be finished. I can say if the community would lighten up and, maybe release a few mods this game would be even better!Though I admit you can say "They took the money and, ran!" you cant blame them after what they have given to us. It is a finished game that I beleive is worth 15$. If you dont beleive me, please try the demo and, see whether it is your cup of tea. Gameplay reviewThe game is highly replayable with diffrent challanges rising, and some just repeating. Your successes may be minor at first but they get bigger and, bigger, and even bigger as you continue through the game! Once you mastered one floor, suprise there is another full of harder, and newer enemies. You can send your soldiers down, but do you want to risk a seige assualting your town when it is ungaurded? "Oh no! Robert Died!", these all arise in your game, and I assure you it is a intresting game when on hard difficulty.RatingsCommunity: 7/10Gameplay: 9.5/10Replayability: 9.5/10Major Update Frequency: 2/10Minor Update Frequency: 7/10Features: 9/10StyleStoryline: GeneratedCharacters: RandomizedArt: BlocksMobs: FictionalWeapons: VariedArmors: VariesCrafting: YesRTS (Total War): NoRTS (City-Builder): YesSimilar Game: Geomoria, Tropico (Similar in the way you build the town, and buildings but not directly control the people's choices.)Recommended?: Yes! But please try the demo first!

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Ok, first off, I just want to say that this review should be taken with a pinch of salt. This game has had an intense history for the time it's been around, and after witnessing a fair bit of it first-hand, I can say it wasn't pretty. I'll explain further on, as it does actually have a small amount to do with this review, but for now, let's get to it: Is the game good, and what's it about?What is Towns?: Towns is a top-down isometric strategy-RPG-simulation thingymabob. Most easily compared to Dwarf Fortress, it contains similar mechanics but without as much complexity. You control a small group of townies which require food, shelter, and equipment to survive. The world contains many dangers that will constantly threaten your civilization as you explore the underground dungeon for sweet loot, and farm the terrain to create vast fields of food. Everything can be controlled with your mouse with ease, from planting and building to digging and fighting. Of course, if you want to use those hotkeys to be a bit faster, then I don't blame you. You'll probably need them. While the art style may not be to everyone's taste, it's easy on the eyes and makes the world interesting to look at, providing you with plenty of colors to play with and enjoy.Reasons it's good: I've personally been a big fan of games like these since I found dwarf fortress a while back. So, I decided to pick this game up on sale and give it a bash. And I can honestly say I had fun. The overall simplicity of it made it easy for me to jump into it and understand most of what was going on right off the bat (though that may be in-part from having played similar games before-hand). The game looks pretty good most of the time, the blocks you can use to build have a lot of variation and color to them, so you can create some really nice looking builds. The A.I. has been a bit derpy sometimes, and I found myself often needing to fiddle with what my townies were doing regularly, but that's kinda what you'd expect to put up with when going into a game like this. When it boils down to it, I don't think towns is a game meant to be played with a hardcore mindset like one would play Dwarf Fortress with. The game is a lot simpler, and I found it to be a good game to play on my laptop in bed before going to sleep.Reasons it's bad: Now, some of the things that were good about it, worked kind of liked a double-edged sword. Yes, I had to fiddle with my little civilization, but it wasn't on things I wanted to do. Usually I had to deal with occasionally derpy A.I. that did silly things like leave items laying around that needed to be stored, or not building things correctly. Granted, these were problems I had some time ago. I haven't played much of the game recently (which I'll explain why in a moment), so I do believe some of those A.I. issues may have been resolved. The art style, while nice and simple, is maybe too simple, and could've used something to make it feel a bit more... energetic maybe? I guess beauty lies in the eyes of the beholder, but I think most people would agree that it's not a fabulous looking game. Good, but not fabulous. The simplicity, while nice for this game, could've used a few more things. Maybe a quest system, or thirst. Perhaps bigger maps would've even helped. Just some stuff to make it feel a bit meatier is all. Now, if you haven't figured it out yet, you should be wary of the game's history. If you want to dig deeper into it, go read the game's forums or discussions in the community hub. A VERY small summary of it could be boiled down to: The dev's got burnt out, people got upset, game slowed to a near-death crawl, and hasn't really recovered. The updates are few and far between, mostly consisting of bug fixes and patches. So don't be too hopeful about new content for the game, since in all likelihood, this is about as close as it'll get to a final product. Final Thoughts: I really, really can't hate too much on this game. I had fun with it for the time I played it, and I got my money's worth. But I can't whole heartedly recommend it either (at least at full price), so if it's on sale for a few bucks, then by all means, pick it up and give it a shot. I really only lost ~5$ on the deal, so I'm not too sour about it. For 5$, it was a nice, relatively relaxing game. There is the issue of the game's future though. Honestly, I'm not going to be the optimist, because from what I've seen and heard, optimism won't change much, if anything. I will say though, that I don't believe calling the game dead or abandoned is suitable either. Perhaps we can say that the game has become a husk, an empty shell of sorts. Or perhaps even more correct, would be to say it's a game that's suffered grievous wounds. The game has a chance to recover, and to stand back on its own two feet. Will it ever be what people hoped for? I doubt it. Will the community ever fully recover? Probably not. But, sometimes these things happen. Being too optimistic for something that very well may end up as a dead game is just as harmful as calling it dead outright. I'd love to see this game get built upon, and see amazing thigns happen. But after the toxicity I've witnessed, I'm not sure it's realistic to expect this game to be any more than a game you play in bed for an hour or two to chill to with some music in the background and a nice beverage. So if the game's ever on sale, and you need a nice game to fall asleep to (Warning: do not fall asleep to this game. Shut it off, and THEN go to sleep, lest your town become a graveyard), then pick it up for a few bucks and maybe buy a new CD from your favorite band with the money you saved. Like I said earlier though, take this review with a pinch of salt. While it is much simpler than Dwarf Fortress, it still has those FUN* mechanics in there under the layers of color, loot, and vast quantities of skootenbeeten. If you're not into the idea of watching everything you build up die from rogue werepigs, then buy with caution.Side Note: As it is somewhat important, it should be noted that the lead developer has been the focus of a lot of the controversy surrounding this title. While this should not be a major factor in your decision of buying/not buying this game, I do recommend at least making yourself aware of the situation with the developers. The details can be found by hunting around in the forums and whatnot, but here's a small summary to at least give you an idea: The toxicity of the community can really be traced back to the almost non-existant PR of the developers. After tensions rose, the lead developer was accused of basically taking the money and running, leaving behind a game that to most people (myself included) seemed like little more than an early access title. After minimal updates, and a new Dev that didn't stick around, things weren't looking good for the game, and still aren't. So if you have problems with supporting a company that made some mistakes from day 1, and ended up making themselves look untrustworthy, then take an extra pinch of salt with your final decision. I do believe though that the game should be viewed as it is, which at this point is something more closely relatable to a game you'd play in bed as I said earlier, without believing that it's a horrible piece of abandonware. 'Cus really it's not. It's a small game, not meant to be played on a bigger, more hardcore scale. It's got enough depth to keep you busy for a few hours at least, but not enough to really justify spending elongated hours on it. Regardless of what the developers did, or what the community says, it's a nice little pick up to add to your library for a couple bucks on sale.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Towns could be a great game. It has a lot going for it. From the unique perspective to pleasing graphics it has the base to be a enjoyable time sink. Unfortunately the execution leaves a bit to be offered.The game itself is quite good. You control a group of townspeople who have started a town that happens to be on top of an active dungeon system. You go through the usual gathering and building phases, but are also tasked with dealing with monsters. As you begin to dig into the earth looking for resources you find caverns and tunnels populated by the genres classic baddies. Everything from spiders to ogres await you hapless townsfolk as they dig deeper. You have to build up a guard force to keep you town safe from these creatures, and at a certain point you can even attract "adventurers" that are much more powerful and able to really beat down some baddies. It's a fun mix of dungeon discovery and building and offers quite a bit of content as is.The bad part of it is that you can only pretty much count on it "as is" the "early access" part of this game is seriously slow. There have been exceptionally long gaps between developments, at some points even rumors development had stopped. Issues between developer and publisher have not helped things. So if you're willing to shell out for the game as it is now you will get quite a bit of content, just don't rest any solid hopes on it advancing. The chances of it ever actually being finished and brough inline with the initial goal of  the game is even less. Because of the issues I simply cannot recommend this game to someone. If there were regular updates and some progress towards completion I would completely back this game, but as I can't recommend a game I don't think is ever going to be completed for someone to buy.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												Do NOT, under any circumstances, buy this game. It is STILL unfinished, nowhere near completion, and will most likely never be done. The developers haven't been active for months and sent the alpha out to die. Early Access was introduced partially due to the bloody mess of this game's "launch", and yet it never actually received the Early Access tag, and instead is being sold disguised as a finished product.Not much has happened since then, and it is unlikely that this is going to change in the near future. Yes, it has its charme, yes it had potential, but this potential has not yet been touched by the developers - and this game launched on Steam A YEAR AGO!If you are a fan of this type of game, I wholeheartedly recommend Gnomoria, which is not only cheaper, but also well underway to being a finished game. It wears its Early Access tag with pride, and releases patches very frequently. Just this week they released version 0.9.2, which tweaks, rebalances and fixes a LOT of combat mechanics, and the game itself works and looks charming. While not done yet, it is very much playable without the level of frustration Towns will give you.Stay away from Towns.
