number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Alright folks, the game doesn't deserve all the hate. Well, ummm, actually it does, but not to this extent. I originally bought the game at version 8 (now it's version 14e), so yeah, I'm amongst those who were "cheated" by early promises, and I will still give this game a thump up.Why it does deserve the hate? Because it's clearly unfinished.-Several in-game features are clunky, for example ordering your troops around: you can't simply say "go there", you can only place patrol points. So exploring the dungeons beneath the surface is like: right-click somewhere, place waypoint, wait until they get there, right-click on waypoint, remove waypoint, right-click somewhere else, place waypoint, wait until they get there, etc. Since there's no other option I can live with it, but I'm not lovin' it.-Poor pathfinding. The townies may just ignore the roads, although they walk parallel with them only one square away.-AI is lacking. The haulers tend to choose stuff to pick up far, far away, instead of that exact same thing they are standing on. And, please, don't go to sleep or eat when several dozens of spiders are besieging the town. Also, don't try to gather loot in the middle of the battlefield, because it's dangerous to your health.-The variety of stuff to build is a bit underwhelming, although not always. For example you can build one type of wooden chair (not counting that one which needs gold besides wood), but at the same time there are like twenty stone wall styles. So building homes is not on Sims level.I think these are the negatives worth mentioning, may update if I encounter something I haven't written here yet. Umm, okay, others may say the music is repetitive, but I don't mind, it's not horrible.Why it does not deserve this much hate:- Contrary to a lot of other reviews, I have not encountered _any_ bugs, at least not apparent ones. No memory leaks. No hangups, no slowdowns, no CTDs. I don't really get what others mean when they describe this game as "buggy as ****". There were a lot of them in earlier versions, but right now this is one of the most bug-free games I ever played.I will not make a list about other pros, because they are subjective. I just leave here this: I still prefer Towns way over Gnomoria, and if it was a terrible game I wouldn't have come close to play it for 270 hours. Not many of my games can boast that much playtime.Thus, I dare to say, if you like building towns from blocks, and if Towns is on sale, try it.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Pro:Finished and relatively bug free.Ability to give units tasks (and thereby automate your "Town")Dungeon crawling in addition to town/city buildingLots of crafting / buildingResource managementCon:Devs abandoned the game14.99 price tag is a bit steep (get it on sale)Can be rough for beginners / learning curveBecause the game has been abandoned doesn't mean the game is horrible just no additional patches, content, etc for this game.Personally, I enjoy this game.  It took a bit to figure out but there's a wiki because what game doesn't have a wiki these days ( http://towns.gamepedia.com/Towns_Wiki ).  You can get most/all the information you need to be able to play the game here as well as access to mods or where to get mods.I like how you're able to relocate/make resource areas to where you want them.  In a lot of these games, generally they just regrow in an area that you've already harvested or you have to craft a special/specific building to harvest any additional resources.  In this game, you can take saplings/seeds/fruit/etc and create an area where you'd like them to grow.  Flowers, trees, etc will still grow in other areas but this allows you to have say 5x5 of trees (for lumber) that will continually regrow in that exact same plot (after being chopped down, a sapling will begin to grow in it's place and after a few minutes you'll have a fully grown tree... this applies to wheat, fruit, etc.).  This makes your villagers much more efficient at gathering and better for your resource management.  It is also significantly safer than traversing the area filled with random monsters like brownies, goblins, ghosts, etc.The big downside of the game is that a lot of people feel it isn't "finished" or "unpolished" and the lack of further development.  However, the game is fully functional and the balance may be a little off but that's easily adjustable via the xml files or mods.  Also, game can be pretty brutal at times such as when you expand a bit too early or get raided by monsters and your villagers have no armor nor weapons at their disposal in addition to their piddly health pool.If you like these kinds of games (city building/resource management) and don't mind that there won't be able more updates then buy the game but I'd recommend waiting until it's on sale.  Even if development has stopped, there's a lot of mods for the game which add content or change texture packs, etc.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												I am not one to write lengthy, detailed reviews, but I must say that this game is definitely misunderstood by many.If you are looking for a game in which every detail is given to you, where there is nothing to be learned and no difficulty in creating things, then continue no further.If you are someone who likes unique, one of a kind games that contain many interesting elements native to that game alone, then I do suggest Towns. It is a somewhat addicting city-builder with both rpg and survival aspects. Building is complicated at first, even for simulation and survival vets like myself. Even after the horribly furstrating first attempts at creating a town, I find myself coming back. It's definitely a challenge at first, but as you slowly get a grip on the isometric perspective and somewhat aggravating UI, you begin to discover new things and gain new knowledge, and that is part of what makes this game so golden.The game isn't broken, it is just difficult at first. It definitely is not for everyone, but if you want a unique, expansive, and nostalgic city-builder, please buy this game. You will not regret it.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												I enjoyed the game. Having seen the game when it was in early access the game has come a long way. My only complaint is that the player never has to go to the dugeon and the game implements no way to force the player to enter the dugeon. Another downside is that the villagers will crawl up through the ceiling if there is a hole instead of using the front door.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												The difficulty of this game is making your townies happy. You have to make a lot of things to make them happy, but they have to build/make it and work makes them unhappy! It's a very slow game, and if you want to, as long as you have things being made constaintly without you telling them to on your own using the auto-craft, then you can have the game run all night. Carefull about autosaves when you do this. It may not work out like you want and you'll end up with a town of ghosts! Dispite all that, I find that it's not too daunting to take on this challenge and there are now tutorials up to get you started on your way to create the best town you can. Don't forget, you can turn some townies into soldiers to protect them at the cost of them not acutally crafting things, but at least you can protect them. They can also protect themselves you outfit them  properly as well. Just try it out and have fun with it. If the game you are working on doesn't work out, you can always make another, thankfully.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I really enjoyed the game. It's a shame about what happened with the development but the game as it is already has a lot of features, and the modding does expand that. I do find myself playing this again from time to time, and I never actually been able to reach the deep levels yet. The game is not easy for newcomers and a lot of people will die most likely, but with practice and some tricks eventually you can get a decent town running.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												As one of a million "build a world" style games I enjoyed this one a lot based on the semi-automated NPC stuff. I found that the game made it really difficult to start actually staging in the deeper levels of the dungeon. You couldn't build much sustainable food underground, and otherwise had to manually have people go drop food for your NPCs to eat. Made the later game a little annoying.But the building system worked really well, and I enjoyed being able to set up an entire economic supply chain for your NPCs to follow.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Bought this over a year ago, and I loved it then (83 hrs). I've read about the new updates, and I can't wait to play it again.Towns can be difficult to learn at the beginning of the game. It has a deep level of complexity due to how flexible it is for player building. You do not get complete control over your villagers. Rather, you place a series of instruction for your villagers to follow. As is typical for town building games, your villagers can be pretty dumb sometimes, but that is all part of the fun. You think that you are safe to leave your people to work on the things that you assign them, and sometimes, things go horribly wrong. I've had several cities that have failed horribly, but I have no problems restarting. It just gives me more delivery and more fun.
